Award.AwardTitle: MONOLAYER CATALYST AS TRANSFORMATIVE CONCEPT FOR EFFICIENT ELECTROLYTIC HYDROGEN ISOTOPE SEPARATION

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1605331
Brankovic, Stanko R.
The study examines the effects of positive strain in platinum (Pt) and palladium (Pd) monolayer catalysts on the efficiency of electrolytic hydrogen isotope separation in applications such as separation of heavy, deuterated water (D2O) from normal H2O. Improved separation efficiencies would aid the production of cheaper moderator materials for current fission-type nuclear reactors and provide crucial fuel components for future fusion reactors. These technologies would help to achieve a secure energy future for our Nation while promoting safe nuclear energy implementation and proliferation. More broadly, the techniques developed for hydrogen isotope separation can also be applied to a host of other electrolytic isotope separations.

The idea is built on the premise that positive strain in a metal monolayer-thin film, induced by epitaxial misfit with a substrate, increases the strength of the adsorbed hydrogen bond in the overpotential region where recombination of hydrogen atoms is the rate determining step in the hydrogen evolution reaction. As a result, an increased hydrogen isotope separation efficiency of Pt and Pd monolayers is expected as compared to bulk Pt and Pd electrodes. The positive strain also increases the surface diffusion barrier for adsorbed hydrogen atoms. This effect favors recombination of isotopes with smaller mass. As the surface is stretched, the neighboring adsorption sites separate from each other which affects heavier hydrogen isotopes more and results in their lower probability for recombination thus increasing separation efficiency. To study these strain effects in Pt and Pd monolayer catalysts we propose to synthesize continuous Pt and Pd monolayers on Au(111) using electrochemical deposition and deposition via a surface-limited redox replacement reaction pioneered by the principal investigator's group. The adsorption strength of hydrogen isotopes will be studied by infra-red spectroscopy. These results will be used as starting input in our DFT calculations and theoretical analysis. The calculated ratio between the rates of hydrogen and deuterium recombination and separation factors for Pt and Pd monolayers and corresponding bulk electrodes will be compared to experimentally measured ones. If necessary, additional sophistication of theoretical model/calculations in terms of the input parameters, approximations and considered effects will be implemented. This iterative procedure will help to gain full understanding and quantification of separate strain effects on separation efficiency of Pt and Pd monolayers. Furthermore, the project will provide a highly inter-disciplinary learning environment for graduate students involving elements of electrochemistry, materials science, and catalysis, all critically important for technological leadership of our country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcome of the performed research is that successfully demonstrates fundamental advantage of the strained catalyst monolayer over its bulk electrode for efficient hydrogen isotope separation. This is demonstrated by example of Pd monolayer Au substrate.  The general agreement between the theoretical calculations and various experimental methods unquestionably establishes the fact that the tensile strain in Pd monolayer benefits the hydrogen isotope separation efficiency by having a 20% higher value of separation factor (Sk) as compared to the Pd bulk electrode (Figure 1). Although the engineering of the catalyst monolayer activity through the later strain is well known in electrocatalysis, this is the first time that this concept has been studied and proved beneficial for hydrogen isotope separation application. Therefore, the performed research activities and results serve as an example of the universality of scientific concepts and their use across different disciplines on a new set of problems.

The activities in this research project have also led to a discovery of the electroless Pb monolayer deposition phenomenon. This presented the opportunity for further advances of catalyst monolayer and catalyst core-shell configurations synthesis. The new deposition phenomenon has been combined with metal deposition via surface limited redox replacement reaction which led to design of the two step process so called the electroless (e-less) atomic layer deposition (ALD), Figure 2.

The performed work and results have a broader significance in the field of chemical separations, electrochemistry and heterogeneous catalysis. The knowledge acquired during this project can be extrapolated to other reactions and isotope separation where kinetic isotope effect and heterogeneous catalysis play an important role. For the energy sector, which becomes a dominant driving force for the US economy, these results indicate a valid route for cheaper production of the important moderator materials for fission reactors (D2O), and potentially crucial materials for future fusion reactor operations. This research provided a base for two PhD thesis and one MS thesis. It also created conditions for unique educational and research environment for graduate students who developed a complex set of skills which are in great demand in USA economy. This research formed a base for long term collaborations between several research groups with complementary expertise in the areas of DFT calculations, analytical chemistry, electrochemistry and catalysis, optics and plasmonics, x-ray characterization and image science. No doubt, all of them have the highest relevance for the US economy and technological leadership in the world.
